CatDescriptText: William Carson, steelworker, Lawrenceville and Evelyn Scott, housewife, Edgewood, were part of Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 13, 1960, pg. 1 with question: "What are the most appealing and least appealing aspects of the Democratic Presidential candidate, Senator John F. Kennedy?"  Mr. Carson's answer reads: "His most appealing aspect is the fact that he's a Democrat. He will get my vote."  Mrs. Scott's answer reads: "I think that he's too aggressive.  He should be tamed down.  I'm not for Kennedy, but I like his smile."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Carson wearing straw hat with striped band, eyeglasses, and plaid shirt, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Evelyn Scott wearing short sleeved plaid dress with two dark buttons, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
